title-group.article-title: The Impact of Firm Ownership Structure on Voluntary Disclosure: Empirical Evidence from Czech Annual Reports*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2004 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We investigate the impact of ownership structure on the extent of voluntary financial disclosure by examining the cross‐sectional variation in the extent of disclosure by newly privatized Czech firms. Owners derive benefits directly from the firm (private benefits of control) and from changes in share values in the capital market. Both these benefits are affected by disclosure. Consistent with owners’ attempts to maximize their total benefits, we find that the extent of disclosure is positively related to investment fund ownership at low levels of fund ownership but is negatively related to investment fund ownership at high levels of fund ownership.

fn.p: We are grateful to Jana Matesova (Czech Management Center); Jacob Birnberg, Harry Evans, Lawrence Feick, Esther Gal‐Or, and Ken Lehn (University of Pittsburgh); Katherine Schipper (FASB); William Lanen, Douglas Skinner, and Jan Svejnar (University of Michigan); Vaclav Skolout (Prague Stock Exchange); Stan Baiman (University of Pennsylvania); Rene Stulz (The Ohio State University); Howard Thompson and Terry Warfield (University of Wisconsin—Madison); and Ivan Zelenka (Prague School of Economics) for helpful comments and discussions. We are also thankful to an anonymous referee for several useful suggestions. This research has also benefited from comments made at seminars at the University of Pittsburgh, The Ohio State University, University of Michigan (Davidson Institute), the KPMG Peat Marwick–sponsored American Accounting Association International Conference, and the Annual Conference on Financial Economics and Accounting (SUNY, Buffalo). This research was funded in part by the International Business Center and by the Institute for Industrial Competitiveness at the Katz Graduate School of Business of the University of Pittsburgh. Contact the corresponding author, Anil K. Makhija, atmakhija.1@osu.edu.

body.p: The purpose of this article is to examine the impact of ownership structure on the extent of voluntary financial disclosure by firms. Although prior research has investigated the importance of managerial ownership for specific accounting policy choices,1Marston and Shrives’s review (1996) of the extensive literature on the determinants of disclosure reveals that the impact of ownership on the extent of overall disclosure has not yet been examined empirically. In this article, we investigate the cross‐sectional variation in the extent of disclosure in 1993 annual reports of the newly privatized nonfinancial firms included in the Prague Stock Exchange 50 (PSE 50) index, after controlling for nonownership factors suggested by previous research.

We choose Czech annual reports from 1993 for our analysis because this period permits us to conduct a unique natural experiment for studying the impact of ownership on the extent of voluntary disclosure. First, the ownership structure of Czech firms was largely exogenous in 1993. In contrast, in more developed capital markets such as the United States, where the ownership stakes held by investors can be relatively easily changed and may be affected by the disclosure policies pursued by firms, ownership and disclosure are endogenously determined. Second, the early years of the transition to a market economy constitute a special window in which Czech authorities provided firms wide latitude regarding disclosure choices in annual reports. With the substantive forms of financial reporting still evolving and careful enforcement of the extant disclosure requirements unlikely, Czech companies’ annual financial reports of 1993 were largely voluntary in nature. In comparison, studies of the extent of voluntary disclosure in U.S. financial reports must appeal to choices beyond the substantial requirements of the “basic framework and minimum standard” (Lang and Lundholm1993, p. 246).

Czech privatization has produced both external (e.g., investment funds) and internal (e.g., insider managers) equity owners whose incentives concerning public disclosure in annual reports may differ. We study the impact of these different types of owners on disclosure. In our conceptual model, we explicitly recognize (1) the agency‐based direct benefits of ownership, or private benefits of control, along with (2) the more obvious benefits owners derive through increases in the value of their shares because of lowered cost of capital. Based on the attempts of owners to maximize their total benefits, 1 plus 2, we formulate hypotheses regarding the impact of external and internal ownership on the extent of disclosure by firms. We are particularly interested in the impact of ownership by investment funds on the extent of disclosure. With limited wealth in the hands of individual investors and political factors restraining foreign ownership, investment funds emerged from the 1992 Czech voucher‐based privatization scheme as large block holders in many firms. Indeed, few Czech firms were privatized with foreign ownership or direct domestic sales (e.g., purchases by insiders). As large shareholders, investment funds might be expected to play a major, beneficial role in the corporate governance of the newly privatized firms in their portfolios (Shleifer and Vishny1986,1997). However, as Coffee (1996) points out, investment funds have been accused of using the resources of these firms for their own benefit, affecting other shareholders adversely. Such self‐interested behavior by investment funds may also affect the extent of disclosure by firms. In this article, we examine owners’ incentives and present empirical evidence about their effect on firms’ disclosure policies.

The analysis in our article is presented in two steps. First, we measure the level of disclosure in annual reports by constructing a number of indexes. We identify a list of disclosure items and determine what fraction of these items is disclosed in a given annual report. Second, we examine the cross‐sectional relations between our 1993 disclosure indexes and the stakes of external and internal claimants, after controlling for other factors that have been found to affect disclosure, for example, size, profitability, intangible assets, size of bank debt, type of industry, issuance of securities, type of auditor, and listing status (Cooke1991,1992,1993; Lang and Lundholm1993; Skinner1994; Meek, Roberts, and Gray1995; Raffournier1995; Patton and Zelenka1997). Our findings strongly support the notion that ownership affects the extent of disclosure in annual reports (Smith1976). Most importantly, consistent with our hypotheses, we find that the extent of disclosure is positively related to investment fund ownership at low levels of fund ownership but is negatively related to investment fund ownership at high levels of ownership. We also find that concentration of ownership significantly affects the extent of disclosure.

In the next section, we describe the ownership structure of newly privatized Czech firms and explain why the development of Czech disclosure requirements yields a natural experiment. InSection II, we formulate hypotheses regarding the impact of ownership structure on voluntary disclosure. InSection III, we describe our data and methodology. Our findings are inSection IV. A summary and a conclusion are inSection V.

fn.p: For example, the effect of managerial ownership has been analyzed with respect to the reporting of accruals (Warfield et al. 1995), oil reserves (Craswell and Taylor1992), share options (Forker1992), forecasts (Ruland et al. 1990), and depreciation method (Dhaliwal, Salamon, and Smith1982).

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Ownership Structure and Financial Reporting in Newly Privatized Czech Firms
sec.p: The purposes of this section are (1) to briefly describe the ownership structure of newly privatized Czech firms and the development of Czech accounting reporting requirements and (2) to point out why a study of 1993 Czech annual reports constitutes a natural experiment to study the impact of ownership structure on the extent of disclosure.2

fn.p: For more details regarding the privatization process in the Czech Republic, see Claessens (1997), Claessens, Djankov, and Pohl (1997), Hingorani, Lehn, and Makhija (1997), Mejstrik and Burger (1992), Svejnar and Singer (1994), and Kotrba (1995). For more details regarding the development of Czech accounting requirements, see Patton and Zelenka (1997).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Ownership Structure of Newly Privatized Czech Firms and Development of Czech Accounting
Ownership Structure
sec.p: Soon after the collapse of the communist regime in November 1989, a market‐oriented government started the process of privatizing businesses in the Czech Republic. While smaller firms were privatized through a variety of means, most of the equity of large firms was transferred to private hands through the voucher privatization scheme. Some 988 large firms were privatized in the first wave of the voucher scheme by five rounds of bidding carried out from May through December 1992. Other large firms were privatized in the second wave, which was completed in October 1994. All of the firms in our study were privatized through the voucher scheme during the first wave. As part of the voucher privatization, the Czech Ministry of Finance collected and disseminated information on the ownership structure of firms. In particular, the ministry published ownership data by specific investment funds as well as by several classes of owners, that is, direct domestic sales (blocks sold to Czech investors), foreigners, restituents, government, and individual small investors for the 988 firms privatized in Wave 1.3

We refer to ownership by investment funds and restituents as external ownership. Investment funds were created as privately owned mutual funds to help individual Czechs invest during the privatization process. Because the interests of mutual fund managers and firm managers often diverge, we treat investment fund managers as external owners. We also treat restituents as external owners because they were also not aligned with internal owners.

Unlike external ownership, information regarding internal ownership of privatized Czech firms was not available directly. However, following Hingorani, Lehn, and Makhija (1997), we treat all ownership created through direct domestic sales and through sales to foreigners prior to the voucher scheme as internal ownership. Purchases of shares by management insiders are included in these direct domestic sales. However, since managerial ownership was not reported separately, other domestic buyers are also included in the direct domestic sales. Because direct domestic sales prior to the voucher scheme were difficult (or even impossible) to arrange without management cooperation, we believe that the other purchasers in this category are also equivalent to insiders. Similarly, since these early foreign investors could not acquire stakes in state‐owned enterprises without the consent and support of managers, foreign buyers prior to privatization are more like insiders than independent external investors.

fn.p: Restituents are original owners whose property was confiscated by the communists and later restored to them as part of the privatization process after the collapse of the communist regime.

sec.title: Development of Czech Accounting
sec.p: The Velvet Revolution of 1989 started a series of sweeping changes in the Czech political economy, affecting the way businesses organized, operated, and reported (Dyba and Svejnar1994; Schroll1995). The accounting and reporting changes were introduced in a new Commercial Code law as well as in a new Czech Act on Accounting (1991), Czech Securities Act (1992), and Ministry of Finance Decree (1993) on footnotes to financial statements.

The research reported in this article analyzes the extent of disclosure in the annual reports (“vyrocni zprava”) of the firms in our sample. Although annual reports were mandated by the Czech Act on Accounting, the act did not provide much guidance concerning the specific form and content of annual reports (Zelenka, Seal, and Sucher1996). In addition, the Act on Accounting did not provide for noncompliance penalties or for a mechanism to enforce the law. Thus, Czech firms could follow their own interests regarding the extent of disclosure in their 1993 annual reports.

Although the regulations concerning annual reports were quite flexible in 1993, other types of financial disclosures in the Czech Republic were more closely regulated. For example, companies were required to submit very detailed financial statements to the tax and statistical authorities on forms prescribed by the government. In addition, the Czech Securities Act directed publicly traded companies to prepare year‐end reports (“rocni zprava”), which were to include financial statements for 3 years as well as a fairly extensive set of footnote disclosures. However, investors did not have ready access to these other reports. As described below inSection III.A, we use the Czech Act on Accounting and the Czech Securities Act as the sources of items in our indexes of disclosure.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: A Natural Experiment
sec.p: A study of Czech annual reports for 1993 constitutes a natural experiment to examine the impact of ownership structure on the extent of financial disclosure by firms because (i) the ownership structure of Czech firms was largely exogenously set prior to the preparation of 1993 annual reports and (ii) disclosure choices were primarily driven by economic considerations rather than regulatory requirements.

First, with respect to the exogenous ownership structure, insider, foreigner, restituent, and government ownership were determined prior to the voucher scheme, and ownership by investment funds and individuals was established by the bidding process during the voucher scheme. Although the voucher scheme was completed by December 1992 and new owners began to take charge, shares were not distributed until May–June 1993. Thus the ownership structure was fixed for the first half of 1993. Also, even though trading opportunities became possible soon after the distribution of shares (the first Registranci Misto System stock auction occurred on July 8), trading volumes were very low throughout 1993, as trading mechanisms were still being fine‐tuned and developed (Hingorani et al.1997). As a result, the ownership structure disclosed by Czech authorities at the conclusion of the voucher scheme remained effectively unchanged at the end of 1993. If share holdings could have been easily changed, both disclosure and ownership stakes would be decision variables that influence each other. Consequently, disclosure and ownership would be endogenously codetermined. As a result, any regression of the extent of disclosure on the ownership stake by a type of owner would estimate only the observed relation between disclosure and ownership stake, and not the impact of ownership on disclosure. Also note that to the extent that financial disclosure and future ownership are co‐determined (as managers and investors anticipate each other’s behavior), the 1993 ownership structure does not fully determine financial disclosure. However, the continued low trading volumes in 1994 (Hingorani et al.1997) suggest that major changes in ownership structure were not expected. Thus, we treat ownership structure as an independent variable that drives the variability in the extent of financial disclosure. There is a complication, however. Since fund ownership was formed after insider ownership was set in the proposed privatization plans prior to the voucher scheme, fund ownership may have been influenced by the expected disclosure preferences arising out of the preset insider ownership. Nevertheless, we might still consider fund ownership as largely exogenous because fund ownership was expected to be dominant in many firms and therefore likely to prevail in setting disclosure policies.

A second factor helping to form the natural experiment is the fact that Czech accounting laws were still under formulation through most of 1993. The laws did not fully specify the form or content of annual reports or state penalties or mechanisms for enforcement in case of noncompliance. Consequently, we can examine whether the extent of disclosure is driven by the economic motivations of owners, rather than simply by a desire to satisfy mandated disclosure requirements.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: We develop below hypotheses regarding the relation between the extent of disclosure in annual reports and ownership structure (subsection A). We also discuss other factors that affect public disclosure (subsection B).

sec.title: Impact of Disclosure on Benefits of Share Ownership
sec.p: Direct benefits or private benefits of control (entrenchment). There are direct benefits from being in control of a firm. These benefits are in addition to the cash flows one receives as a shareholder. The direct benefits, or private benefits of control, are obtained by one group exploiting its position relative to the other stock holders (Jensen and Meckling1976; Demsetz and Lehn1985; Demsetz1986). The private benefits of control are available to both external and internal owners. In fact, there is evidence that large external blocks trade at a premium over ordinary exchange prices and that these premiums are related to the value of private benefits of control (Barclay and Holderness1989,1992). However, since external block holders are not as well positioned as managers to obtain direct benefits, we expect that external block holders require larger stakes than managers before they can have meaningful influence (become entrenched) and consume significant direct benefits. Generally, we can expect that direct benefits of an owner can be enhanced through controlling more voting rights (larger ownership fractions).

Zingales points out that in Italy direct “benefits are particularly large because the legal system is very ineffective in preventing exploitation of a control position” (1994, p. 145). The private benefits of control are also likely to be substantial in the Czech Republic because of an ineffective legal system and the nature of assets and opportunities in a transitional economy. The transition to a market economy proceeded very quickly in the Czech Republic; legal and other governing institutions found it difficult to keep up with the pace of change during the transition. Indeed, there is considerable anecdotal evidence that many investment funds in the Czech Republic have seriously exploited firms in their portfolios, seeking direct benefits rather than maximizing share values. TheNew York Times(Perlez1997, p. D8), citing a U.S. mutual fund president who oversees investments in Central Europe, reports that “in many cases the investment funds stripped the companies of assets, leaving minority shareholders—ordinary Czechs—with nothing.” Apparently, such behavior was so widespread that it earned itself a special name, “tunneling,” a practice by which investment funds siphon away assets of firms and leave behind empty shells. Reflecting the seriousness of the situation and hoping to introduce regulatory reform, the Czech Ministry of Finance (1997) released a document,Current Aspects of the Czech Capital Market, with a list of 15 techniques that the investment funds and their managers were using to enrich themselves at the expense of the companies and the capital markets. One of the ways in which investment funds have exploited their positions is particularly noteworthy because it is likely to persist without major structural reform. Many of the large investment funds were sponsored by banks. The 10 largest bank‐sponsored funds obtained 67% of the investment points acquired by funds (i.e., 44% of all points) in both waves of Czech voucher privatization. The problem is that “the banks and their funds use their shareholder rights not to improve the companies but to line the banks’ pockets through loans.”4Ellerman (1998) also describes various methods used by investment funds to exploit the firms whose shares they hold. Recent press reports affirm such exploitation (Green2001).

Finally, it should be noted that it is in the interest of the controlling ownership group that its consumption of private benefits of control not be easily observable. If such consumption is observed, other shareholders may claim it too. Or, they may try to prevent it by seeking whatever remedies are possible in the weak legal system. Worse, they may publicize and politicize such consumption, thus more effectively jeopardizing it. Consequently, when an owner is pursuing direct benefits, we expect that he will seek to reduce the extent of disclosure: thus, direct benefits are expected to be negatively related to the extent of disclosure. As a result, when we plot the size of direct benefits, (DB) against the extent of disclosure in figures1and2, we depict the relation with a negatively sloped line. Fig. 1.—
Benefits to external ownership.a, Low external ownership.b, High external ownership. SB+DB = total benefits; SB = share benefits; DB = direct benefits.
Fig. 2.—
Benefits to internal ownership.a, Low internal ownership.b, High internal ownership. SB+DB = total benefits; SB = share benefits; DB = direct benefits.

Benefits in the form of share price increases because of lowered cost of capital (alignment). Increases in share prices are an obvious benefit of share ownership. To the extent that a controlling ownership group, external or internal, is focused on the objective of maximizing share prices, its interests are aligned with those of other shareholders. If the primary objective is the maximization of share prices, an owner will seek to increase disclosure because that raises share prices. An increase in disclosure leads to higher share prices because a reduction in informational asymmetry brings about greater liquidity, which, in turn, lowers the cost of capital and raises share prices.5These relations among information asymmetry, liquidity, and stock prices have been developed in a number of papers, including Demsetz (1968), Tinic (1972), Copeland and Galai (1983), and Glosten and Milgrom (1985). The model in Diamond and Verrecchia (1991), and its empirical test in Bartov and Bodnar (1996), arrive at the same relations using accounting disclosures to reduce informational asymmetries. A reduction in informational asymmetry between insiders and outside shareholders, because it impinges on the ability of managers or entrenched large shareholders to consume private benefits of control, also reduces agency problems.

Severe managerial agency problems have resulted in wide informational asymmetries between insiders and outside investors in ex–Soviet bloc countries. During their communist past, according to Frydman and Rapaczynski (1994, p. 145), managers “learnt to consider shirking and illicit appropriation of state property their God‐ (party‐) given right.” The “collapse of the old system has been followed by a mix of aimlessness, political rent‐seeking, asset‐stripping, and corruption” (Sachs1992, p. 43). The extent of agency and related informational asymmetry problems in the transition can be illustrated by the survey results reported for Russian funds by Frydman, Pistor, and Rapaczynski (1995, p. 29). They state that, “most astoundingly, 12.5% of the funds report thatnocompanies in their portfolios give them regular access to financial information, and 49.3% report that most companies do not provide such information. As a result, … the funds resort to spying on their own companies.” The Czech Republic is not immune from these problems, although the situation may not be as problematic as in Russia. The other side of this coin is that, by addressing the agency and informational problems, external owners (investment funds) can significantly enhance share prices. Consequently, share values are expected to be positively related to the extent of disclosure. As a result, when we plot the size of share value benefits (SB) against the extent of disclosure in figures1and2, we depict the relation with a positively sloped line.

fn.p: This observation was made by V. Kreidl, analyst at Patria Finance, a major Prague investment company (Longworth1997, sec. 1, p. 14).

The positive relation between reductions in informational asymmetry and higher stock prices can also be explained in the context of the Myers and Majluf (1984) model. A reduction in informational asymmetry reduces the cost of external finance, and beneficially affects stock prices.

sec.title: The Impact of Ownership Structure on Benefits and Voluntary Disclosure
sec.p: Disclosure and external ownership. Considering first external owners with low share ownership, we expect a positive relationship between preferred extent of disclosure and ownership. This is because external owners, unlike insiders, cannot realize significant direct benefits from the firm at lower levels of ownership; they do not have enough power or influence with low stock holdings. Instead, such owners derive benefits primarily from higher share values. Since greater disclosure leads to higher share prices (Diamond and Verrecchia1991; Bartov and Bodnar1996), external owners with low levels of ownership are expected to seek increases in disclosure by their firms.

Figure 1a depicts the case of low external ownership and shows that DB is at a low level and that it declines slowly with increases in disclosure. External owners with low ownership have low power and influence and derive few direct benefits. Disclosure decreases the ability to consume even these few direct benefits, but the drop in DB is unlikely to be sharp. Direct benefits are probably already at such a basic, low level that there may be little to give up. On the other hand, gains from increases in share values produce meaningful benefits; SB rises more sharply. Hence, total benefits are expected to increase with disclosure. Thus, if ownership is increased, external owners with low share ownership can be expected to seek increases in disclosure.

Based on the above discussion, we state the following hypotheses regarding external ownership:
External Ownership Hypothesis:
A.
At lower levels of external ownership, public disclosure is positively related to external ownership.
B.
At higher levels of external ownership, public disclosure is negatively related to external ownership.

The corresponding testable hypothesis developed in the methodology section (III.A) combines parts A and B of this hypothesis, positing that the relation between public disclosure and external ownership can be depicted by a quadratic function, with public disclosure positively related to external ownership and negatively related to the square of external ownership. Together, A and B imply an inverted U‐shaped relation between the extent of disclosure and external ownership. Of course, whether the curve actually undergoes a change in its slope—that is, the desire to decrease disclosure dominates after a point—depends on the magnitude of the coefficients and not just their signs.

Disclosure and internal ownership. External ownership played a far more important role than internal ownership in Czech privatization. Indeed, there are few cases of nonzero internal ownership in our sample. Nevertheless, we state corresponding hypotheses for internal ownership. The hypotheses are the opposite of those for external ownership. When, on the one hand, internal ownership is low, the benefits of greater disclosure in the form of share value benefits are exceeded by the likely losses in the private benefits of control. On the other hand, when internal owners hold large amounts of shares, the share price benefits are likely to be greater than the losses in direct benefits. These effects are depicted infigure 2and are stated below:
Internal Ownership Hypothesis:
A.
At lower levels of internal ownership, public disclosure is negatively related to internal ownership.
B.
At higher levels of internal ownership, public disclosure is positively related to internal ownership.

fn.p: Obviously, at some high levels of ownership stake, even external owners could be so entrenched that their direct benefits are also largely unaffected by disclosure. We are not dealing with such large holdings by any one external owner in the Czech case (investment funds were limited to a 20% maximum equity stake). A group of funds may together hold larger stakes, but it is an empirical issue as to whether they would compete or collude for direct benefits.

sec.title: Government Ownership
sec.p: There are a variety of reasons that suggest that a larger stake by the Czech government is expected to increase the extent of disclosure, although the behavior of the Czech government under the prior regime suggests a negative effect on public disclosure. These reasons, unlike those underlying our earlier hypotheses, are not drawn from explicit economic trade‐offs. Rather, they are based on general aspects of the situation in the early years of Czech privatization, resulting in a hypothesis with a weak directional prediction.

In many cases, the Czech government held a large equity stake in a newly privatized firm because the plans were to complete the firm’s privatization at a later time. In such cases, we expect the government to prefer greater public disclosure by the firm in order to maximize its share value in the subsequent sale, although the ability of the government to execute its preferences may be questioned. There are also noneconomic considerations, particularly applicable to some very famous firms in which the Czech government chose large stakes, that suggest that government ownership would have a positive effect on the extent of public disclosure. The government chose to hold on to large stakes in firms that were perceived to have strategic value or were considered “national silver.” As a reaction to public outcry over the privatization of certain famous and well‐performing firms, the Czech government held on to shares in some firms. Because of the public interest in these firms and an atmosphere of heightened nationalistic feelings at the time, we expect that greater government ownership would result in more public disclosure for these firms as well.
Government Ownership Hypothesis:
Public disclosure is positively related to government ownership.

sec.title: Concentration of Ownership Hypotheses
sec.p: In order to study the relative ability of internal and external owners to influence the extent of disclosure, we first describe the coalitions or blocks that they represent.

Nature of block holdings. Block holders can be expected to be more effective than individual shareholders in influencing the disclosure choices of management. In fact, we do not treat the holdings of individual owners in a firm as a block in our analysis. This is because each individual received too few investment points in the privatization scheme to acquire a sizeable number of shares in a single firm. As a result, these widely dispersed investors do not have strong incentives to overcome the costs of forming a meaningful coalition to act in concert.

In our analysis, we treat the cumulative holdings by restituents in a firm as a block because of the high likelihood that they belong to a single family (family ownership being the predominant ownership form when the communists confiscated property over 4 decades ago). We also treat the cumulative holdings of some subsets of the external investment fund owners as a block. We do not treat all investment fund ownership as a block, because each privatized firm could wind up with a large number of investment funds as owners. Many of these investment funds would have too small a stake in the firm for them to meaningfully influence the firm’s policies. Also, because of potential conflicts in their investment objectives and the differing interests of their sponsoring institutions (e.g., banks), not all investment funds would have an alignment of interests. Consequently, to avoid any conflicts among the investment funds, we first consider only the impact of the ownership by the fund with the single largest stake. In addition, to test the sensitivity of our results, we also define the block holdings by investment funds to be the cumulative holdings of the investment funds with the five largest stakes in the firm, assuming that this small a group still forms a practical coalition of shareholders.

Concerning internal block holders, we treat internal owners (insiders and foreigners) as a block of owners because of their alignment of interests. Treating insider and foreign owners as a block appears reasonable under the circumstances because protracted negotiations were entailed in establishing an ownership stake and very few parties were involved; these circumstances made cooperation among the parties practical. Moreover, incumbent managers were so strongly entrenched prior to the voucher privatization process that membership in the “management coalition” was a likely precondition to the successful acquisition of ownership stakes by direct domestic or foreign sales. Thus, the various types of internal owners were generally linked in a number of ways and shared enough incentives to reasonably assume that they form a block holding coalition. Block ownership by internal owners is measured simply as the sum of the percentage holdings for the group of insiders and foreigners with stakes in the firm.

Relative ability of blocks to influence disclosure. In our discussion thus far, we have analyzed in isolation the preferences of different ownership block types regarding disclosure policy. However, the ability of a block of owners to influence successfully disclosure practices depends on the size of the stakes of other block holders as well as the extent of dispersed holdings by individual investors. Because our model includes the size of stakes held by each block holder among the potential determinants of the extent of disclosure, we automatically capture (and control for) the effects of the size of each block holder’s stake. However, this step does not reflect the effects of the dispersion of holdings (concentration of ownership) in the firm, which is also expected to affect the extent of disclosure. In particular, the more concentrated ownership is, the greater is the power of the block owners relative to individual dispersed shareholders to obtain their desired outcomes regarding disclosure.7This suggests that concentration of ownership should be included in the model as a determinant of the extent of disclosure. However, this is problematic because the sign on the effect of concentration of ownership on the extent of disclosure is ambiguous and the results would be difficult to interpret. The reason is that, as noted in our hypotheses, disclosure preferences differ according to the identity of the owner and the initial level of his ownership. One way to overcome this ambiguity is to reduce the problem to one type of owner and then consider his preferences at lower and higher initial levels of ownership. As a result, in formulating the hypotheses below we focus on the effect of concentration of ownership on disclosure when one type of nongovernment block holders—external block holders—is dominant. We also condition the concentration of ownership hypotheses on the initial level of ownership by external holders. This leads to the two conditional hypotheses below, only one of which is valid in a given circumstance.
Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis:

list-item.label: A.
list-item.p: When external owners are dominant and the initial level of external ownership is low, public disclosure is positively related to the concentration of ownership in firms.

list-item.label: B.
list-item.p: When external owners are dominant and the initial level of external ownership is high, public disclosure is negatively related to the concentration of ownership in firms.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Other Factors Potentially Affecting Public Disclosure
sec.p:
Based on our review of the literature, the nonownership factors listed intable 1could also be expected to affect the extent of disclosure by firms. Thus, we include them in our empirical model as control variables. While we repeat intable 1the reasons offered in the literature for why these factors might affect the extent of disclosure, it should be noted that the earlier work has not always found each variable to be significant in all settings. Table 1
Nonownership Factors Affecting Extent of Public Disclosure
Variable Sign Explanations
Size + Since there may be a fixed component to disclosure costs, larger firms are expected to have greater disclosure (Lang and Lundholm1993). Also, for strategic reasons, smaller firms are less likely to disclose information (Raffournier1995). Moreover, since damages in securities litigation tend to be higher for larger firms, we expect greater disclosure by larger firms in order to prevent litigation (Skinner1994). Litigation and related damages, however, may not be as important in the Czech case. Finally, larger firms are more complex (Eaton and Rosen1983), making for more informational asymmetry and leading to greater disclosure. Meek et al. (1995) document a positive association between voluntary financial disclosure and size, and note that other international studies also report similar findings.
Profitability +/− As a result of adverse selection, more profitable firms could be expected to have greater disclosure (Lang and Lundholm1993). But this reasoning contrasts with the legal argument that poorly performing firms choose greater disclosure in order to avoid subsequent legal liability (Skinner1994). The empirical evidence on the effect of profitability on disclosure is mixed. For example, Patell (1976), Penman (1980), and Lev and Penman (1990) find that firms with positive earnings disclosure tend to disclose more frequently. This contrasts with the findings of Ajinkya and Gift (1984) and McNichols (1989), which suggest that firms are as likely to disclose positive earnings news as negative news.
Intangible assets + Since firms with more intangible assets have greater informational asymmetry, we expect that such firms will make more public disclosure. Greater disclosure by firms with more intangibles is expected to be motivated by greater benefits from the reduction of agency costs, since there is a positive relation between intangibles (value of growth opportunities) and agency costs (Smith and Watts1992; Gaver and Gaver1993).
Bank debt − Larger bank debt implies greater bank monitoring and, consequently, less need for public disclosure to providers of capital. The need for public disclosure is reduced in the presence of bank monitoring because banks are considered to be superior monitors (James1987). Also, bank debt has a negative effect on disclosure because, as argued by Rajan (1992) and Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1994), once established as a specialized monitor of the firm, the bank can exploit the dependent creditor.
Manufacturing firm + According to Cooke (1992), manufacturing firms tend to disclose more than nonmanufacturing firms based on a study of disclosure by manufacturing and nonmanufacturing firms in Japan. Raffournier (1995) also hypothesizes this effect.
Issue additional equity + According to Myers and Majluf (1984), stock prices react negatively to announcements of secondary issues of equity because of the adverse effects of informational asymmetry between managers and outsiders. Their argument is that outside investors expect the firm to issue equity when stock market prices are higher than their true values, leading investors to negatively adjust stock prices. If informational asymmetry is reduced, additional equity can be issued without drawing a significant negative reaction. Consequently, we expect that firms that expect to issue securities, in anticipation, will make greater public disclosure. Survey and interview data support this relation between security issuance and disclosure (Lees1981; Gibbins, Richardson, and Waterhouse1990). The relation is also supported by evidence that suggests that earnings forecasts are more likely to be made by firms that offer securities (Ruland, Tung, and George1990; Frankel, McNichols, and Wilson1995).
Big 6 auditor + Large, international auditors, such as the Big 6 accounting firms, are expected to insist on greater public disclosure than small Czech auditing firms, because the former have more valuable reputations to maintain (DeAngelo1981; Teoh and Wong1993). Moreover, these firms are perceived to have deep pockets and are likely to seek greater disclosure in order to reduce their legal liability.
Exchange listing + Listing on an exchange is expected to produce greater disclosure because of disclosure requirements by the exchange or because listing is a prelude to the issuance of new securities (Cooke1991,1993).

sec.title: Dependent Variables: Indexes of Disclosure
sec.p: In order to test our hypotheses concerning the extent of disclosure in Czech annual reports, we created operational measures of the “extent of disclosure.” Consistent with other studies of financial disclosure (Marston and Shrives1996), we assess the extent of disclosure by comparing actual annual reports with a set of country‐specific disclosure requirements. As noted earlier, in 1993 Czech laws provided enough flexibility to allow for wide variety in annual reports. Among the available models for annual reports were financial statements that firms submitted to the government, or year‐end reports the firm might have prepared under the Securities Act. Alternatively, the firms could even have relied on non‐Czech accounting principles and practices (e.g., International Accounting Standards, European Union directives) for guidance. This multiplicity of models makes it difficult to establish an unambiguously correct disclosure index for measuring the extent of disclosure in Czech annual reports (Robbins and Austin1986). However, because disclosure rules relating to Czech year‐end reports are fairly specific and comprehensive, we chose the disclosure rules from the Securities Act as the basis for our annual report disclosure index.8See the appendix for lists of disclosure index items.

The annual reports were carefully inspected by two independent coders for evidence about the disclosure of various items. Any conflicts in coding were resolved by joint investigation of the actual annual reports.

fn.p: Our disclosure index cannot be used to measure the extent of annual report compliance with disclosure standards because annual reports (“vryrocni zprava”) were not required to comply with all of the disclosure requirements in the Securities Act. Also note that some firms disclosed information items not included in our disclosure index.

sec.title: Independent Variables: Operational Definitions
sec.p: InSection II, we presented hypotheses regarding the effects on the extent of public disclosure of both (a) ownership structure and (b) other variables used in prior research. In this section, we describe the operational measures of the explanatory variables. Recall that our hypotheses concerning the effects of ownership by internal and external owners each have differing predictions (parts A and B of the hypotheses) depending on the level of (lower or higher) initial ownership. We operationalize these relations between public disclosure and ownership by different stakeholders by using a quadratic function, including (ownership) and (ownership)2terms.

In creating an independent variable to test for the effect of concentration of ownership, we begin by measuring the concentration of ownership using the Herfindahl Index for ownership, HF, calculated as the sum of the squares of fractions of ownership across all owners.9This index ranges from zero to one, with higher values indicating more concentration of ownership. We do not, however, use HF by itself as an independent variable in explaining the extent of disclosure. The reason is that, as pointed out in the development of the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis (Sec. II.A.4), HF (concentration of ownership) has an ambiguous directional effect on the extent of disclosure. To determine the direction in which the extent of disclosure (our dependent variable) is affected by HF, we also need to establish the identity and disclosure preferences of the dominant owner. Focusing on one type of owner, the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis inSection II.A.4is stated in terms of dominant external block holders. Operationally, we identify external block holders as dominant if the sum of share holdings of the investment fund with the largest stake plus the restituents’s stake exceeds the stake held by internal block holders.10Based on this criterion, we set a dummy variable, DEXT, equal to one if external owners are dominant; otherwise we set it equal to zero. As a result, the variable HF*DEXT describes the effect of concentration of ownership on disclosure according to whether or not external block holders are dominant.

The final step in operationalizing a directional prediction for the effect of ownership concentration on the extent of disclosure is to take into account whether the initial level of ownership is lower or higher by the dominant owners. We expect external block holders to pursue more (less) disclosure when their initial levels of ownership are lower (higher). This suggests that, unless the initial level of ownership is specified, the sign of the relation between public disclosure and HF*DEXT will be conceptually indeterminate. However, two factors point to the likelihood of relatively lower levels of initial ownership by external block holders. First, as noted earlier there were constraints on the size of holdings in a particular firm that an individual fund was permitted to acquire.11For example, investment fund regulations required that a fund not invest more than 10% of its capital in any one security and that it own no more than 20% of the nominal value of any securities issued by one issuer. A second factor is that the strongly entrenched positions held by management suggest that a substantial block might be necessary to reach a level where an external investment fund might begin to enjoy insider status and prefer less disclosure. Thus, we expect a positive sign on the HF*DEXT variable (which is part A of the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis). However, if we find a negative coefficient on HF*DEXT, we will conclude that the evidence supports part B of the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis.

The operational definitions of the individual independent variables are intable 2. Table 2

fn.p: In calculating HF, we assume that individual investors’ shares, obtained through the voucher scheme, are small and constitute negligible blocks. This is a reasonable assumption because individual investors received only small numbers of shares as a result of the bidding process in the voucher scheme.

We also use an alternative definition where the funds with the five largest stakes are defined as a block, assuming that the investment funds with the five largest stakes constitute a meaningful block. Both sets of results are discussed below.

Although restituents are included in external block holders, they owned small stakes (average of 0.23% intable 5). Thus, we focus on investment funds here. Including restituents does not affect our basic results.

sec.title: Sample Identification
sec.p:
Table 3lists the 43 nonfinancial Czech firms that were included in the 1993 PSE‐50 index and form the sample for our study. We formed our sample based on the PSE‐50 because the index covers a wide spectrum of industries for which data were likely to be available. There are nine firms in the construction or construction materials business, eight each in the machinery and food and beverages industries, and five in the chemicals and rubber industry. We excluded seven financial firms in the PSE‐50 from our study because of their regulated nature. These 43 nonfinancial firms represent a sizeable portion of the total sales (over one‐third) of the 988 large Czech firms undergoing privatization in wave 1. Data on firm ownership were obtained from a series of publications,Privatizace Kuponova, issued by the Czech Ministry of Finance (1992) in connection with the voucher scheme. Other data were taken directly from the annual reports of the firms in the sample.Table 3also reports the sales of the firms as well as the largest equity block holders. Table 3

sec.title: Sample Descriptive Statistics
sec.p:
Table 4contains descriptive statistics for the 43 nonfinancial Czech firms in our sample. First, note the large cross‐sectional variation in size. While the smallest firm has sales of $12.4 million, the largest firm has sales of $1,746.9 million (panel A). The difference in mean versus median sales ($147.6 vs. $78.4), points to the presence of some relatively very large firms. Similar variation can be seen in the total assets as well. The average firm was profitable in 1993 with mean (median) return on assets of 5% (7%). Among the other selected characteristics of our sample, panel B oftable 4, it is notable that over one‐fifth of the firms employed Big 6 auditors so soon after their privatization. Although all the firms, by design, trade on the Prague Stock Exchange, only a little over half the sample was formally listed on the Prague Stock Exchange. Table 4

sec.title: Sample Firms’ Ownership Structures
sec.p:
The ownership structures for our sample firms are described intable 5. Although the mean percentage of internal ownership is small (5.84%), it is sizable (mean of 25.10%) for firms with nonzero internal ownership. For example, there are 10 cases of firms with internal ownership, but in eight of these companies internal owners own the largest nongovernment blocks. The few cases of nonzero insider (col. 5) or foreign (col. 6) ownership, amounting to a total of only 10 cases of firms with internal ownership, raises the issue of whether this is an adequate sample size for our analysis of internal ownership. Furthermore, underlying this small sample of internal owners are a number of assumptions (we interpret all direct domestic sales as insider purchases and have lumped foreign and insider stakes together), since even insider ownership is not directly reported. In contrast, external ownership by funds and restituents is directly available, with nonzero stakes held by funds in all 43 firms in our sample. Table 5

Note.—Stakes held by funds and individuals are determined based on the outcome of the voucher scheme that concluded in December 1992. Shares were not distributed to owners until May–June 1993 and trading volumes were low in the period July–December 1993. Herfindahl Index, HF, is defined as the sum of the squares of fractions of ownership held by all owners, assuming that the individual stakes (INDV) are very widely dispersed and amount to a negligible ownership block.

External ownership consists of restituent and investment fund ownership, with investment fund ownership defined for block holding purposes as either the holdings of the investment fund with the largest stake or the holdings of the investment funds with the five largest stakes. According totable 5, restituents hold a 0.2% mean stake across the full sample and a 2% mean stake in the six firms in which they have nonzero ownership. In contrast, the mean stake of the investment fund with the largest stake is 12.30%, and the cumulative holdings of the investment funds with the five largest stakes are 38.26%.12If we concentrate on private (nongovernment) owners, funds are the largest block holders in 79% of the companies (34 of 43). Thus, investment funds are clearly important players in the governance of these newly privatized firms. As for external ownership, the mean holdings of external owners, consisting mostly of the holdings of the investment fund, are 12.53% when we include the holdings of the investment funds with the largest stake. As noted above, all the funds together may not represent a meaningful coalition block.

Finally,table 5provides information about the dispersion of shares. During the voucher scheme, individuals (excluding insiders, foreigners, and restituents) acquired a mean (median) stake of 13.5% (14.0%). Given the small number of investment points distributed to each individual, any individual could obtain only a few shares in a firm. This adds to the extent of dispersion in ownership. A more direct measure of the dispersion or concentration of ownership is provided in the table through the HF. The mean value of HF for our sample is 0.1384.

fn.p: The maximum stake held by an individual investment fund in a company is 19.99%, just under the 20% allowed by regulations.

sec.title: Disclosure in Czech Annual Reports
sec.p:
Table 6contains statistics on measures of the extent of disclosure. In panel A, we present statistics on the “Narrow,” “Somewhat Broader,” and “Comprehensive” indexes of the extent of public disclosure for our sample of 43 nonfinancial and 7 financial firms. For the “Narrow” index, the average nonfinancial firm discloses 55% of the disclosed items covered in the Securities Act. Taking into account items that may not be relevant for a given firm, the mean value of the “Somewhat Broader” index is 0.49. Finally, using the broadest definition, the mean value for the “Comprehensive” index is 0.44.13Panel B oftable 6reports the correlation coefficients between the indexes. They are very highly positively related. Table 6

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Results: Evidence on the Impact of Ownership Structure on Disclosure

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Effects of External and Internal Ownership on Disclosure
sec.p:
Our basic methodology consists of regressing each of our three alternative measures of extent of disclosure, the “Narrow,” “Somewhat Broader,” and “Comprehensive” indexes on the ownership independent variables, after controlling for other factors affecting public disclosure. Since the relation between public disclosure and an ownership variable may be masked by multicollinearity, we estimate correlation coefficients and variance inflation factors (VIF) intable 7. Applying the cutoff of correlation coefficient values of 0.8 or higher for multicollinearity to be considered as troublesome according to Judge et al. (1980, p. 459), multicollinearity is not a problem except for two understandable situations. The correlation coefficients between external ownership and its square and between internal ownership and its square are very large (0.97 and 0.91, respectively). Furthermore, except for only external ownership and its square, the VIF values intable 7show that multicollinearity is not a problem for our estimation (use of VIF is considered to be superior to an examination of pairwise correlations in testing for collinearity, according to Berry and Feldman [1985, p. 43]). Only external ownership and its square have VIF values remarkably greater than 10, a number that is used as a rule of thumb as an indicator of multicollinearity problems (Belsely1991). Later we report that both external ownership and its square appear with significant coefficients in our estimations. Since multicollinearity biases thet‐statistics downward, the significant findings for these coefficients suggest that even for these variables multicollinearity is effectively not an issue. As noted before, we have a number of reservations regarding internal ownership, INT and INT2, and the marginal multicollinearity problems intable 7add to these concerns (VIF values of 10.16 and 9.59). Since our disclosure indices (dependent variables) are constrained by definition to values which range from zero to one, we undertake logit transformations (Wonnacott and Wonnacott1979) and employ \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{ln}\,[ \mathrm{Index}\,/ ( 1-\mathrm{Index}\,) ] $ \end{document} as the dependent variables.Table 8, panel A, contains the results for the cross‐sectional regression of the extent of annual report disclosure on only the ownership variables. (The potential omitted variables problem is addressed below.)Table 8provides considerable evidence that the ownership structure of a firm has an important effect on the extent of its public disclosure. The average adjustedR 2for the three regressions reported in the table is 35.38%, suggesting that ownership variables are important because they explain a considerable part of the variation in the extent of disclosure by Czech firms. In each estimation reported intable 8, the coefficient of EXT is positive (significant at the 1% level). The coefficient of EXT2is negative in all cases (again, at the 1% level). Based on the coefficients for the “Narrow” index and taking derivatives with respect to EXT, the slope of the plot of extent of public percentage disclosure against external ownership is \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $0.2116-0.0136\times \mathrm{EXT}\,$ \end{document} . This implies a positive slope from 0% to about 16% external ownership, followed by a negative slope beyond that. Coefficients of external ownership, using the “Somewhat Broader” and the “Comprehensive” indexes, also yield a turning point around 16%. For the average firm, with a mean external ownership stake of about 12.5%, the extent of disclosure and external ownership are positively related. Over the full range of external ownership (EXT ranges from 1.75% to 21.23%), the plot between disclosure and external ownership has the predicted inverted‐U shape, consistent with both parts A and B of the External Ownership Hypothesis. These findings are confirmed using a spline analysis (four 5% ranges for external ownership). We find that when external ownership exceeds 15%, the relation between ownership and disclosure is significantly negative, while it is positive (and sometimes significant) at lower levels of ownership. In contrast to external ownership, almost all of the internal ownership coefficients are not significant intable 8. This is inconsistent with our Internal Ownership Hypothesis.14The coefficient of HF*DEXT is highly significant (1% level) and positive in all three estimations intable 8. The implication is that concentration of ownership has a positive impact on the extent of disclosure, when external block holders are the dominant group, supporting the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis (part A). Finally, government ownership is not significantly related to the extent of disclosure, based on the lowt‐statistics of the coefficients of government ownership intable 8.

While multicollinearity was not found to be of major concern (table 7), heteroskedasticity and omitted variables problems remain to be addressed. According to panel B oftable 8, heteroskedasticity is also not a concern (see Cook‐Weisberg tests). As for the omitted variables problem, it also does not appear to be a major issue. First, in two out of the three estimations reported in panel A oftable 8, the Ramsey tests suggest that the omitted variables problem is not significant. In the third estimation, using the “Narrow” index, there is only a hint of a problem, since the tests show weak significance (p‐value of 10%). Although a strict interpretation of these econometric tests may lead one to conclude that the ownership structure is the only determinant of disclosure, there are nevertheless reasons to consider the impact of nonownership factors. For one, the average adjustedR 2in the table is only 35.38%, leaving about two‐thirds of the variation in disclosure unexplained. Two, several nonownership factors have been found in prior literature to significantly affect the extent of disclosure (seetable 1for a summary of this literature). Consequently, we repeat the analysis intable 9after including other explanatory variables. Table 9

The average adjustedR 2for the three estimations contained intable 9is 39.88%, which is greater than the average adjustedR 2of 35.38% obtained intable 8, panel A, using only the ownership variables. We find that the impact of the ownership variables intable 9is essentially the same as intable 8, supporting the External Ownership Hypothesis but not the Internal Ownership Hypothesis.15Again, as before, part A of the Concentration of Ownership Hypothesis is supported intable 9by the positive coefficients on HF*DEXT which are significant at the 1% level.16Finally, with respect to government ownership, we find that the coefficients on government ownership are positive in each estimation but are not statistically significant in any case. In contrast to the results for the ownership structure variables, the control variables intable 9appear to play a less important role in explaining the extent of public disclosure in Czech annual reports.17Among the control variables, the dummy variable for the use of a Big 6 auditor has the strongest and only significant effect on public disclosure. The coefficient of DBIG6, as predicted, is positive (at the 5% level of significance in two estimations).

fn.p: There are several data‐related reasons that may explain these findings. The reasons, as pointed out before, include a small sample size of nonzero cases of internal ownership, the possibly noisy ownership data, and the potential for multicollinearity problems.

In order to use the full sample, in one case (Podnik Vypocetni Techniky) the ROE was not available and the sample mean ROE was used intable 9. Similarly, the sample mean INTG/TA value was used for BARUM, Sigma Dolni, and Prazske Pivovary. Repeating the analysis, after dropping the four observations with missing data, does not materially affect the findings.

When HF is included by itself as an independent variable, we find that the coefficient of HF is positive and significant. This positive coefficient, without taking into account the dominant owner (e.g., multiplying HF and DEXT), would be consistent with either the preferences of external block holders with low initial level of ownership or the preferences of internal block holders with high initial level of ownership. Our approach to measuring the effects of ownership concentration allows us to refine the test and makes the results easier to interpret.
The industry dummy is not significant. Using separate dummies for the three most common industries (construction, food and beverages, and machinery) also did not yield significant results.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Robustness of Findings Regarding External Ownership: Alternative Estimations
sec.p: To check the robustness of our findings we also repeat our analysis intable 9(including the nonownership variables) with a number of alternative definitions for external ownership.18

Alternative (i), stake held by the fund with the largest stake in the firm: When we remove the holdings of restituents from our measure of external holdings, defining it as simply the holdings of the fund with the largest stake in the firm, our earlier findings are corroborated. The coefficient of external ownership is significant and positive for all three estimations using our different measures of the extent of disclosure. As before, the coefficient of the square of external ownership is significant and negative for all three estimations. Based on these coefficients, the plot of the extent of disclosure against the holdings of the fund with the largest stake in the firm is again an inverted U.

Alternatives (ii) and (iii), sum of the stakes held by the funds with the five largest stakes in the firm, and sum of stakes held by the funds with the five largest stakes plus restituents’ stake: Again, the coefficients of external ownership and its square are significant with the signs predicted by the External Ownership Hypothesis.
These findings, employing a variety of alternative measures of external ownership, suggest that our earlier findings in support of the External Ownership Hypothesis are robust.

fn.p: Recall that thus far we have defined external ownership as the sum of the equity stake held by the fund with the largest stake plus restituents’ stake.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Summary and Conclusions
sec.p: Using 1993 annual reports for the nonfinancial firms in the PSE‐50, we test several hypotheses. Supporting our hypotheses, we find that the extent of disclosure is positively related to investment fund ownership at low levels of fund ownership but is negatively related to investment fund ownership at high levels of ownership. These findings suggest that, despite the substantial ambiguity and uncertainty about financial reporting regulations and the lack of recent experience in external financial reporting, Czech firms generally did respond to their economic situation in a predictable manner.

Our finding that ownership structure is a significant determinant of the overall extent of disclosure provides two important extensions for the literature on financial disclosure. First, although several authors have found a relationship between managerial ownership and specific accounting choices (e.g., accruals; see Warfield, Wild, and Wild1995), this study documents the effects of a broader set of owners on the overall extent of disclosure. Second, this study provides evidence on the impact of ownership stakes held by external owners on the extent of disclosure, rather than on merely the relationship between ownership and the extent of financial disclosure.

Finally, our findings have implications for the corporate governance of newly privatized firms. With limited wealth in the hands of individual investors and political factors restraining foreign ownership, investment funds are one of the few viable block holders for the large number of newly privatized firms in Eastern and Central Europe. It is expected that investment funds, as large block holders, will find it economical to provide valuable monitoring and will have a beneficial effect on share values. While this effect of block holdings is valid up to some point, our findings suggest that Czech investment funds with larger holdings (equity stakes greater than 16% or so) may be pursuing private benefits of control over increases in share prices. Perhaps, expecting such self‐serving behavior at higher levels of ownership, Czech regulators limited the maximum equity stake that an investment fund could hold (to 20%).

sec.title: Items Included in “Narrow” Disclosure Index

list-item.p: 3 Date of establishment of company disclosed
25 Aggregate compensation of board members disclosed
63 How many years balance sheets (3, 2, 1, 0: count as three items, 1 per year)
71 Number of shares of contributed capital disclosed
82 How many years income statements (3, 2, 1, 0: count this as three items)
91 Distribution of last year's profits disclosed
94 How many years' cash flow statement (3, 2, 1, 0: count this as three items)
96 Indirect method of cash flow statement used?
111 Marketable securities (current asset) valuation method disclosed
114 Investment securities (noncurrent asset) valuation method disclosed
135 Market value of fixed assets disclosed
152 Evidence of bad debts accounts disclosed

sec.p: There are 37 items in this “narrow” index. The number in front of each item refers to its coding sheet reference. Disclosure of each item is required for financial statements under Czech laws or ministerial decrees. As used by Cooke (1992) and others, each “yes” item is scored as one; each “no” item is scored as zero in the numerator of a disclosure index. The denominator equals the number of “yes” plus the number of “no” answers. “Not applicable” items are excluded from the index.
